advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for correspondance courses using MPF-1 computers.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR TECHNOLOGIES CREATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The conbination of Victor Business Products and Sirius Systems Technology Inc. creates a new company designed to meet the most demanding needs of the modern business office...<br> ... The result is Victor Technologies Inc., a company idally suited to dramatically impact today's international computer marketplace.<br><br> The Chairman of the board of the new Victor Technologies in Fred Sullivan, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Kiddle, Inc., a diversified $3 billion company. The financial support of this giant conglomerate will help focus Victor's goal of becoming one of the three leading computer companies in the world.<br> President and Chief Executive Officer of the new company is Chuck Peddle. Acknowledged as the "father" of the personal computer concept, Peddle introduced this useful and very affordable third generation micro-computer in the European market with startling results..</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JUPITER BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (RECTO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''For less than 2000 francs, offer yourself the future'' ...yes</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BAKED APPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PICTURE (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used for promoting Educatel, a French private computing school.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (NOV. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Same offer and same sale prices as in December 1985</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (OCTOBER, 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Particuliar sign : painter and musician''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - JAN.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...If you want a computer that won't be obsolete in a few years, buy an MSX.<br> If you want one of the best-selling MSX computers in Japan, buy a Toshiba HX10.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Here comes Sirius 1 : the micro-computer which has an elephant memory"<br> ...<br> "A new era for computing"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This surprising advert is dated 1982.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #6</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Laser 100/110 was the first model of the Laser 100/200/300 family.
The ROM was nearly identical to the one of the Tandy Radio-Shack TRS-80 Color Computer, with only minor changes. It's so close that when people write Laser emulators, they use TRS-80 CoCo ROM documentations (Laser detailed documentations are hard to find, especially about the ROM itslef).
The Basic was a Microsoft Basic just slightly modified to avoid lawsuits, some statements being stored in the ROM but not available on the machine!
Like the most of the Vtech products, the Laser 100/110 was "cheaply" conceived: chicklet keyboard, plastic case, light-weight... It was produced to compete against the first wave of micro-computers like the famous Sinclair ZX-81.
The difference between the Laser 100 and the Laser 110 must be the RAM size (like the Laser 200 and 210), though very little information on the Laser 100 is available.
The biggest difference with its big brother the Laser 200 was that it only had a black & white display.
An obscure VZ-100 version was also released but this wasn't the same machine as the VZ series sold in Australia and New-Zealand by Dick Smith Electronics. _______________________
computer.keyboard: QWERTY, 45 rubber keysBasic instructions and graphic symbols
computer.name: LASER 100/110
computer.ports: Tape-recorder (600 bauds), RF tv out, Composite video out, Memory upgrade port, Expansion port
computer.ram: Laser 100 = 2 KB or 8 KB?Laser 110 = 4 KB or 8 KB ?Upgradable to 64 KB

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The spongy keyboard doesn't allow fast typing.<br> Most of the keys have 4 functions: letter, graphic symbol and two Basic commands.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Laser 100-200 series were probably the most poorly manufactured computers ever seen. Glue was used instead of connectors for the keyboard cable, the main power condenser was also sticked to the case. Notice also the mass of solder used to join the metallic cover with other components.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Except for the Motorola 6847 video chip, all other main chips are located below the metallic protection which is soldered to the main board. Not really easy for servicing.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • 9V external AC adaptor jack<br> • Tape recorder jack<br> • Composite video jack<br> • Memory expansion connector<br> • Peripheral connector<br> • RF/TV output</blockquote>
